translated: The fundamental treatise accepts that causes are only of six kinds, neither more nor less. The first is the capable of producing cause, the second is the co-existent cause, the third is the similar cause, the fourth is the associated cause, the fifth is the pervasive cause, and the sixth is the karmic maturation cause.
The essence of the capable of producing cause is common to all dharmas, therefore it is mentioned first.
Because the substance of the simultaneous cause is found in all conditioned dharmas, it is placed second.
The remaining similar causes, etc., include a small part of conditioned dharmas, as is appropriate, and are explained in order according to the convenience of expression.
Because it is relied upon by dharmas that are born, it is called a cause. These six causes are not taught by the Buddha. How can the Abhidharma treatise establish this name?
There is definitely no meaning that the Great Master did not teach, and the Abhidharma treatises do not arbitrarily teach anything.
It is not presently found in the sÅ«tras because it is hidden.
Its own characteristics can be obtained, and it definitely must exist.
Moreover, it is because of the power of those to be converted that the World-Honored One skillfully teaches using different approaches.
The Abhidharma masters know that it definitely exists by seeing a small characteristic. Because it is clearly compiled, some say:

Just as the meanings of the four conditions, although fully listed in this school's sÅ«tras, there are those in other schools that do not recite them. Because of the long passage of time, much has been lost.
Since we see that other sÅ«tras have some omissions, we know that this place is also not complete.
Moreover, we see that the sÅ«tras are scattered here and there, so the meanings of the six causes must definitely truly exist.
That is to say, as the sÅ«tras say:
The eye and form as conditions give rise to eye-consciousness.
And as the sÅ«tras say:

These and others are the efficient causes. All dharmas have the meaning of being able to make something else. Because they are unobstructed in arising, this cause is established.
As a scripture says:
There are three factors of the path, with right view revolving.
Also, as a scripture says:
The union of the three is contact, with feeling, conceptualization, and volition arising together.
These are the coexistent cause. All dharmas that arise simultaneously and perform the same function are established as this cause because they revolve together.
As it is said:
Such a pudgala accomplishes good dharmas and bad dharmas.
One should know that such a pudgala, with good dharmas hidden and bad dharmas appearing, still has good roots that accompany and follow.
Because they are not yet cut off, there is still the meaning of being able to give rise to other good roots from these good roots.
Also, it is said:
Bhiká¹£us!

If one frequently follows and investigates this and that, then one's mind frequently enters into this and that. Ignorance is the cause for giving rise to various defilements. Understanding is the cause for being free from various defilements.
These are called homogeneous causes. Past and present homogeneous dharmas establish this cause by drawing forth their own effects.
As a scripture says:
View is the root of faith, realization, and wisdom.
Also, as a scripture says:
If there is discrimination, then there is knowledge. When one is concentrated, one's knowledge is called true, not when one is not concentrated.
These are called associated causes. The mind and mental factors are associated in performing a single function, establishing this cause by jointly taking a single object.
As a scripture says:
All bodily actions, speech, and mental actions of one with wrong views, all vows and aspirations, all activities are of that kind, and all these dharmas are able to bring forth undesirable results.
Also, a scripture says:
When all views arise, they all take the view of a real self as their root.
If this view arises and one does not tolerate anything, this view can give rise to greed and anger.

These are the universal causes. Doubt, views, and ignorance that are eliminated by seeing suffering and its cause in the past and present, and their associated and coexistent [dharmas], give rise to defiled dharmas of the same and different kinds. Therefore, this cause is established.
One part becomes the cause and gives rise to the fruits of the five parts. Therefore, outside of the homogeneous cause, the universal cause is established.
As a sutra says:
If the karma that is done is good and contaminated, and is accomplished through cultivation, one is born in that realm and experiences various retributions.
Also, as a sutra says:
All intentional karmas that are done and increased definitely attract retributions.
These are the causes of retribution. All unwholesome and wholesome contaminated dharmas attract different kinds of retributions. Therefore, this cause is established.
These six causes are taught by the Buddha in various places, but those who are averse to them do not see them because of their confusion.

Moreover, the World-Honored One has said in various sutras that there are innate and prior causes. Based on this, that exists; because this arises, that arises. One should understand the meaning of the first two causes accordingly.
Moreover, the World-Honored One has clearly explained the meanings of the two causes in the sutras. A sutra says:
Those who are not diligent in the realm of ignorance, due to ignorance, also create meritorious actions.
This sutra clearly shows the existence of prior causes.
Moreover, a sutra says:
The eye and form as conditions, and so on, up to the mind and dharmas as conditions give rise to defiled attention born of delusion.
Among them, the deluded and ignorant are ignorance.
Desiring is craving, and craving indicates karma.
This sutra clearly shows the existence of innate causes, because it speaks of mutual causality within a single moment of mind.
The meaning will be further discerned in due course.
The causes have been briefly presented, and now they will be extensively discussed.
First, what are the characteristics of the primary cause?
Verse:
Except for itself, the rest are efficient causes.
The treatise says:
This efficient cause is of two kinds: one has the power to produce, the other merely lacks obstruction.
When dharmas are born, except for their own substance, all dharmas are efficient causes, because when they are born they do not obstruct. Among them, a small part has the power to produce.

translated: For example, when a single eye consciousness is born, it takes the supported eye as the supporting cause, it takes the perceived form as the establishing cause, it takes eye consciousness, etc., as the seed-like dharma as the uninterrupted cause, it takes the associated dharmas as the embracing cause, it takes the co-existent dharmas as the assisting cause, and it takes the ear faculty, etc., as the abiding cause.
These are collectively called the efficient cause. Among them, a part is called the powerful cause, because it has the ability to produce superior function.
The remaining parts are called the powerless cause, because it merely abides without obstruction.
Although other causal natures are also productive causes, the productive cause has no other name, just as the sense base of form and so on are generally called by the name of a particular instance.
Why is it that one's own nature is not the productive cause of itself?
Because the productive cause does not exist with regard to one's own nature.
The meaning of nonobstruction is the productive cause. One's own nature always obstructs itself.
Moreover, all dharmas, not depending on their own natures, should always be established, because of the loss and so on.
Other masters say:

If the cause of one's own nature is one's own nature, then ignorance would still take ignorance as its condition, up to and including old age and death, which would still take old age and death as its condition.
In a single moment, this would be the cause of this, and this would contradict the nature of dependent origination.
Other masters say:
One does not see a function with regard to one's own nature, and therefore it is not a causal condition, just as the tip of a finger, the edge of a sword, the eye, and so on.
If all dharmas except for itself can be the efficient cause of this one dharma, then the uninterrupted karma would also be the efficient cause of the noble path. How could this be reasonable?
Moreover, only when arising, by abiding without obstruction, can it be a cause. It should not be in other states. It is not reasonable that sometimes it is a cause and sometimes it is not a cause.
When the noble path arises, it is definitely a cause. Therefore, in other states, it does not mean there is no cause.
If in this life it can be an obstruction but is not an obstruction, it can be established as a cause.
However, that which has no obstructive function in this life, even if it is not an obstruction, how can it be a cause?

Because all dharmas, in mutual comparison, all have the power of obstruction, they can be causes.ğŸ”½That is to say, in this place, there is this one dharma. In this place, it is not possible to have a second.
Even if this dharma exists in another place, there is also no possibility of having another dharma.
Are not all these dharmas mutually related and able to be obstacles?
But they are not obstacles, and therefore all can be established as being efficient conditions.
The formless realm also sometimes relies on samÄdhi, and therefore there is also the power of mutual obstruction.

Moreover, when a single dharma arises within all dharmas, like desire, all the others are without obstruction. That is to say, dharmas are unable to arise for two reasons: first, the concordant cause is absent; second, the opposing condition is present.
When dharmas are about to arise, they must rely on the powerful specific causes and conditions and on the remaining unobstructed abodes.

The dominant condition is such that dharmas arise due to the presence of the productive cause and the absence of the obstructive cause. Therefore, all dharmas are said to be efficient conditions only due to the absence of obstruction, not because of the presence of the power of obstruction and the absence of obstruction.

As for those that have the power of non-obstruction but are not obstructive, when there is non-obstruction, there is little difference. Both have the power of non-obstruction and the same superior function.
For this reason, all the difficulties raised by others have been eliminated.
If all dharmas are causes of other dharmas because they do not obstruct their arising, why do not all dharmas arise simultaneously?
When one person kills, why do not all people become offenders along with the murderer?
We reply, we say that dharmas are causes of other dharmas only because they do not obstruct their arising. They do not have any positive efficacy.
How can contact with ashes and thorns be a cause of pleasant feeling?
Contact with ashes and thorns is not a cause of pleasant feeling, because it is a cause of a cause. That is, it is a homogeneous cause.
Painful feeling can be a cause of pleasant feeling, because contact with ashes and thorns produces painful feeling, which in turn is a cause of pleasant feeling.
In the same way, seeing, etc., have some small efficacy in relation to each other, and this should be explained in detail.
We have briefly discussed the four topics of the aggregates, sense bases, sense fields, and contact. The rest can be understood by analogy and we will not elaborate further.

Therefore, the active cause, with regard to the effect that it generates, not only does not obstruct, it also has the power to generate. However, it lacks the intimate cause and the cause that is the initial activity, and for that reason all dharmas cannot be generated suddenly, just as it is not the case that all who kill become guilty of the offense of killing.
Past dharmas are active causes for the other two time periods and are dominant results of those two time periods.
Future dharmas are active causes for the other two time periods only because they do not obstruct.

The two time periods are not simultaneous with or subsequent to the future, and therefore they are not dominant results of the future. A result must be taken up by a cause, and for that reason there are only two causes.

We admit that the active cause is found in all three time periods only in the sense of nonobstruction.ğŸ”½Present dharmas are active causes for the other two time periods, and the other two time periods are dominant results of the present.

Conditioned dharmas are causes and results of other conditioned dharmas. Conditioned dharmas are neither causes nor results of unconditioned dharmas. Unconditioned dharmas are neither causes nor results of other unconditioned dharmas. Unconditioned dharmas are causes of conditioned dharmas but are not results of them.
For this reason, it is said that there are many productive causes but few dominant results, because all dharmas are productive causes, and only conditioned dharmas are dominant results.
Thus the characteristics of the productive cause have been explained.
What are the characteristics of the second, co-existent cause?
Verse:
Co-existent causes are mutually results, like the primary elements and the characterized,
and the mind and mental factors.
Commentary:
If dharmas are mutually dominant results, they are mutually co-existent causes, because they mutually assist each other in arising.
What are their characteristics?

The four primary elements mutually serve as co-existent causes for each other. Although there are those with increased substance and those without increased substance, they all mutually serve as causes in three ways. Because one's own substance should not depend on one's own substance, and because one should not depend on the substance of the same category.

Each of the four primary elements only depends on the other three. Because only when the four primary elements are gathered in different categories does it have the ability to produce derivative form.
Thus the characteristics of conditioned dharmas and the characterized, as well as mind and mental factors, are also causes for each other.
This is the coexistent cause, which comprehensively includes conditioned dharmas as its fruits according to their respective [categories].

The characteristics of causes stated here are too few, because mind and mental factors and the characteristics should each be said to be coexistent causes for each other. Therefore, it is also not correct to say that only those that are fruits for each other are coexistent causes.
Dharmas and their characteristics are not fruits for each other, yet they are causes.
Therefore, the characteristics of causes should be further discussed.
For this reason, the term characteristics should be discussed.
One conditioned dharma can be a coexistent cause for many fruits, because the Abhidharma treatise states it this way, and there is no fault in this.
However, in the Abhidharma treatise, it is never said that form that is concomitant with mind is a cause for mind. The intention of the author of this treatise should be discussed.
Some say:

This is a statement with remainder, revealing the faults of the opponent's theory, not a statement establishing one's own position, because the meaning of the statement is incomplete, and is therefore a fault in the argument.
There is another opinion:

Here the proponent of the doctrine is not fully explaining the characteristics of coexistent causes, but is only refuting the doctrines held by other schools. In order to refute the view that there is only mind, he says that there are mental activities apart from mind.
Also, in order to refute the view that action is only volition and there is no unmanifest action, he further says that there are bodily and verbal actions that accompany mind.
Also, in order to refute the view that the characteristics of birth, etc., do not exist as real entities, he further says that there are dissociated formative forces that accompany mind.

Isnâ€™t it the case that the characteristics of coexistent causes are more clearly established by this full explanation, and that mental activities, bodily and verbal unmanifest action, and the characteristics of birth, etc., definitely exist separately?
Also, the characteristics of coexistent causes have never been fully explained elsewhere, and if they are not fully explained now, there is a deficiency.
Therefore, the opponent should reflect:

We see this meaning in this treatise: If a dharma is definitely produced together with mind, is found in all minds, and evolves supported by mind, then that dharma is said to be a simultaneous cause with respect to the supported mind.
Mental activities are not necessarily produced together, sometimes being few and sometimes many, as is evident.
Bodily and vocal actions are not found in all minds, because they are not found in the concentrated mind.
The characteristics of birth, etc., evolve supported by mind, but they do not mutually support each other, because birth, etc., are all headed by dharmas and mutually assist each other.
Therefore it is not said that they are causes of each other.
Also, in this treatise, it is only said that heterogeneous dharmas are simultaneous causes, and it is not said that homogeneous dharmas are causes of each other, even though they are.
Also, in order to show that there is bodily and vocal action that is supported only by mind and not by the revealing form, it is not said that they are causes of mind.
Moreover, the intention of the great virtuous ones is difficult to understand, and those with wisdom have not yet fully understood it. Therefore, there are some who make this conjecture:

Only the mind can be the coexistent cause for the mind and the concomitant form, not form for the mind, because it arises from the mind and depends on the mind, like a king and his ministers, with the superior not being the cause of the inferior.
This conjecture is unreasonable, like a minister and a king, because they have mutual power in defense and support.
What is the essence of the dharmas that are concomitant with the mind?
Verse:
The mental factors, the two types of precepts, and their characteristics, as well as those of the mind,
Are the dharmas that are concomitant with the mind.
Commentary:

All the dharmas that are associated with the mind, the two types of precepts of meditation and purity, those dharmas and the characteristics such as birth of the mind, these are all called the dharmas that are concomitant with the mind.
Why are their secondary characteristics not mentioned?
The reason for not mentioning them will be explained later.
Why are these dharmas called concomitant with the mind?
Verse:
Because of time, effect, goodness, etc.
The treatise says:
In brief, because of ten kinds of conditions such as time, effect, etc., and goodness, etc., it is called mind's concomitant.
As for time, it means that this [dharma] is born, abides, and ceases together with the mind, and falls into the same time period.
As for effect, etc., it means that this [dharma] has the same effect, outflow, and ripening as the mind.
As for goodness, etc., it means that this [dharma] is the same as the mind in being wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
Why not simply say that they are born, abide, and cease together, and thereby understand that they also fall into the same time period?
Although it is understood that they fall into the same time period, it is still not clear that these dharmas are not separated from the mind in the past and future.
They are also not separated.
Or, in order to show the dharmas that do not arise, it is further said that they fall into the same time period.
In that case, one should simply say that they fall into the same time period.
It is not so, one should not cause it to be understood as definitely falling into the same time period.
Are not the same effect and the effect of retribution also included in the category of one effect? Why then do you speak of the same effect and the effect of retribution outside of one effect?

This is true, but the term one effect here only includes the effect of the dominant condition and the effect of disconnection. Aren't these also included in the term same effect and effect of retribution?
Although they are also included, they are not what is being discussed here.

However, the effect of the dominant condition is generally of four kinds: simultaneous, immediately antecedent, separated, and unarisen. This shows that it is not an effect that exists simultaneously with its cause. In order to refute the view that the effect of the dominant condition is only that which arises simultaneously with its cause, namely the aggregate of causes and conditions, because the aggregate of causes and conditions is the effect of each other, and the effect of the dominant condition is not the effect of its own nature, it is shown that the effect of the dominant condition is not the aggregate that arises simultaneously with it.
Among the effects of the dominant condition, there is the meaning of one effect. Therefore, the same effect and the effect of retribution are mentioned separately.
One should understand that in this context, the terms one time and one effect refer to simultaneous and common, but their meanings are different.

The mind-king, even in the least, is a simultaneous cause of fifty-eight dharmas, namely, the ten great fundamental mental dharmas, their forty innate specific characteristics, and the eight fundamental and derivative specific characteristics of mind, called the fifty-eight dharmas.
Among the fifty-eight, excluding the four derivative specific characteristics of mind, the remaining fifty-four are the simultaneous cause of mind.
Why are the derivative specific characteristics of mind not the simultaneous cause of mind?
Because the mind is not born by their power, because mind is not their result, and because they have the function of only one dharma.
Also, because they are not the same result as the mind-king, and because the majority in an aggregate is not their result.
For this very reason, as explained above, the many causes, the derivative specific characteristics, are not called dharmas that accompany mind.
If that is so, how can mind be their simultaneous cause?
Because in the states of birth, etc., they are caused to arise by following the mind-king.

Donâ€™t you know that the great elements are the simultaneous cause of mind? That is, just as derivative form is not the effect of arising, etc., arising, etc., are not the simultaneous cause of the great elements. The same is true of mind and the great elements.
The reason given in the above objection is not equal to the case being illustrated. The one effect of the transformation of the series is not the effect of the great elements.

Not all derivative form is categorized as the one effect of the transformation of the series of the great elements. How can it be that derivative form is not the effect of arising, etc., of the great elements?
This is the same as the error in the above objection.
What is the error referred to above?
Because mind is not born by the power of the great elements.
However, the great elements are born by the power of the transformation of the series, and therefore there is no error.

Other masters say that of the fifty-eight dharmas, only fourteen are causes of mind, that is, the ten universal dharmas, the four dharmas of mind as feeling, etc., and the four fundamental characteristics of mind. The characteristics of arising, etc., of mental activities are not able to be causes of mind, just as the characteristics of mind are not.
If this is so, then it contradicts the Abhidharmapitaka, which says:

There is a truth of suffering that has the view of self as its cause, but is not a cause for the view of self, namely, all defiled truths of suffering except for future views of self and the arising, old age, duration, and impermanence of dharmas associated with it.
There is a truth of suffering that has the view of self as its cause and is also a cause for the view of self, namely, the above-mentioned dharmas.
They say:
We do not recite the words and dharmas associated with it. One should select the meaning of the text and recite it according to the principles.
If it were otherwise, then the characteristics of coexistent causes would be destroyed, or one would have to admit that characteristics also are coexistent causes.
There is another explanation:
All members of the same group are mutually coexistent causes. When any one member is missing from the group, the remaining members do not arise.
Of all these explanations, the first is the best.
Also, in this simultaneous and united aggregate, there are those that are transforming but not following transformation, namely the mind king;
there are those that only follow transformation, namely form and dharmas not directly associated with mind;
there are those that are both transforming and following transformation, namely mental activities, because they follow the mind and transform dharmas not directly associated with mind;
there are those that are neither, namely excluding the above characteristics.
How can there be a causal relationship among simultaneous dharmas?
Why is it known that there is none?
Because simultaneous dharmas, when about to arise, are not yet arisen and should all be nonexistent. How can it be said that they can give rise to each other?
Also, because it is said that where there is a cause, there is an effect.
If dharmas in the future can give rise to each other, there would always be the fault of dharmas arising.
Also, there is no definite proof that simultaneously arising dharmas are effects or causes of each other, like the two horns of an ox.
In the world, seeds and sprouts, etc., are well known as cause and effect, but no one has ever seen cause and effect as simultaneous.
Therefore, how can you speak of cause and effect in the case of the simultaneous arising of dharmas?
We will now explain the characteristics of cause and effect, so that you will know that there is cause and effect in the case of simultaneous arising.

In the previous brief discussion of the characteristics of causes, we cited the BhagavÄn's teachings in various sÅ«tras, saying that when this exists, that exists, and because this arises, that arises.
The opposite of this is non-existence and non-arising. This is called the general characteristic of cause and effect.
The first part clarifies the meaning of simultaneous cause, while the latter part further clarifies the meaning of prior arising cause.
If this is so, then there definitely is no simultaneous cause, because the BhagavÄn said that when this exists, that exists. Since the future does not yet exist, how can it be a cause?
This criticism is not valid, because there are not many kinds of causes, and because the future is not non-existent. This will be discussed in detail later.
Moreover, this sutra proves that the future exists, or they should explain the meaning of the sutra without contradicting reason.
Here, the elder interprets the meaning of the sutra, saying:
When this exists, that exists means that the continuity of causes exists first, and then the continuity of effects abides.
Who arises first?
Who abides after arising?
In order to answer this, it is further said because this arises, that arises.
This shows that the arising of causes comes first, so that later effects arise and continue to exist.
In this way, the elder merely follows his own feelings, falsely understanding the Buddha's sutras to support his own meaning.
Such an interpretation of the Buddha's sutra has no definite cause that can be used as evidence.
That is to say, what definite cause is the evidence for the statement when this exists, that exists? It is only based on the continuity of causes and effects, not on each individual cause and effect.
Based on a single moment of cause, there is a single moment of effect. This accords with correct principles;
because this would contradict correct reasoning.
Also, the explanation they offer is not based on any superior principle, and it does not reveal the wondrous meaning of the scripture.

If you say that the cause and effect of a single moment are difficult to understand, and therefore the scripture speaks of cause and effect in terms of a continuous series, this is also incorrect, because it is impossible for it to be so.
It is impossible for a series of causes to occur without being separated by a series of effects, and it is impossible for a series of effects to occur without being separated by a series of causes.
If you explain the scripture in this way, you must admit that the World Honored One spoke incorrectly, or else that the scripture does not refer to cause and effect in terms of a continuous series.
This explanation makes the meaning of dependent arising difficult to understand, and therefore you should offer another explanation of the meaning of this scripture.
Also, on what principle do you definitely interpret the former scripture as referring to a continuous series, but not the latter?
The latter scripture should also be interpreted as follows:
The arising of this exists because that arising exists means that the continuity of causes exists first, and then the continuity of effects exists.
In that school, there is no difference between the meaning of arising and the meaning of existence, just as there is no difference between the time of about to arise and the time of about to occur.
Moreover, the question raised:
Who arises first?
Who abides after having abided?
This also is unreasonable, because the two gates do not depend on each other, and because the meanings of the two gates that are depended on are different.

It is not the case that what was previously explained as this existing, that exists again depends on the later explanation of this arising, that arises, meaning that what was previously explained as this existing, that exists does not depend on the question of who arises, that arises, and only becomes understood when combined with the later explanation of causes arising, effects arise.

Just as what is later explained as this arising, that arises must depend on the question of who arises, that arises, and only becomes clearly understood when combined with the separate explanation of causes arising, effects arise,

Thus, the former statement, â€œWhen this exists, that exists,â€ also requires a question, â€œDependent on what does that exist?â€ It also requires a separate explanation, â€œDependent on causes, that exists.â€ The meaning is then clear.

Therefore, the two statements are different. Thus, the first sÅ«tra passage I cited is to show the meaning of the cause of simultaneous arising, and the second sÅ«tra passage shows the meaning of the cause of prior arising. The reasoning is completely established.
